You had been an adult, sure, for three months now, but it didn't change much. You just coudn't lie to your mother, she was like a living truth detector. She worked with junkies, drunkards, and poor but smart people, so she had to be. And every single day you skipped school she treated like a signal you'd never finish your education. Sometimes you could count on your father, but you were sure that after two weeks of your absence he would take her side. Well, your neighborhood had changed a lot. It wasn't safe then. Drunk, aggressive men bothered the passers-by, even during the day. Your parents constantly reminded you to watch your steps because of shards of broken bottles lying everywhere. At night, no reasonable man dared to go into the park. Alice Rosset sacrificed her life to the idea of equal rights for men and women. Apparently, her idea lost a lot in abstraction, and as a vengeful spirit ''Auntie'' preferred the concrete. It sobered her up a little. <span class="oliviafemaletext">"Who'd have known that occultism is so messy,"</span> she murmured. <span class="oliviafemaletext">"But it was worth it, don't you think?"</span></p>[["My balls for your soul, fine deal to me"]] [[“You should've asked me before you did it.”|"You should ask me before you did it."]] <<nobr>><<if $oliviaPlan==false>>[["What did you do, exactly?"]]<</if>><</nobr>> <<set $count = $count+1>><<nobr>><<set $count = $count+1>><</nobr>><p>You and ''<<print $they.oliviaFemaleName>>'' went quickly to the school building. Before you went to sleep and began this meaningful dream, you took a shower. Hot water refreshed you a bit. You were out of school for two weeks. It was a lot for an eighteen-year-old guy. It was a surprise that high school life, which seemed to be made of terribly boring things and it was awfully repetitive and predictable, suddenly sped up when you caught this flu. So you were thinking about tomorrow. And you were thinking about your life. It was late April, and after summer you would start a senior year in ''Rosset High School''. How was your life? Assign the number that describes you best. 0 - you don't feel you have achieved much in that aspect, 1 - you have some achievements in that aspect 2 - you achieved much in that sphere. Add a comment, where you describe what helps you succeed."</p> <<if visited("New character") ==1>><div class="hintboxOwn">'''The Parity'' is an RPG game. As many games of this genre, there are stats that describe your character and his (soon her) possibilities. Some stats are public - like ''Approaches'' which show the way ''<<print $you.maleName>>'' handles challenges. There are six ''Approaches'': Careful, Clever, Flashy, Forceful, Quick and Sneaky. ''Approaches'' will change dynamically through the scenes and influence the choices you can make. But most stats are secret, like your Status stats. The character creation is one of a few occasions when you see some of them. Condition, Conflicts, Grades, Popularity and Privacy are the Status stats which form the base to determine your relations with other people. You can see their influence on your school life in the frame below the character creation. Status stats will change as the consequence of your actions that affect other characters in the game. A little more detailed description of the ''Stats'' can be found [[here|Descriptions]].</div><br><</if>><div class="hint" align="center" style="width:200px;">Remaining choices: <<print That was an ultimate proof that it wasn't ''<<print $they.robertName>>'' who stood behind your transformation. Well, that was the first sight.</p>[[You looked closer.|Try them]] [[Your weren't interested.|This last evening]] <<nobr>><<if visited("Try not to sleep")==1>><<set $count = $count+1>><</if>><</nobr>><div class="hint" align="center" style="width:250px;">''Your resistance'': <<print $resistance>></div><p>Maybe you weren't on set of "A Nightmare on Elm Street", but it turned out that dreams were exhausting. You were young, many times you couldn't sleep or sleep a few hours and remained focus and conscious. Luckily, you had a lot of coffee in your home. Your father was drinking liters of it while working on big projects. You didn't like the coffee he bought, it was definitely too strong and sour for you. You remembered what he said to you once: "I don't drink it because of its taste, but because of abilities to raise up the dead". You needed something like that. But well, you were tired. You saw and experienced many exhausting things. Maybe part of this tiredness was caused by ''Auntie''. Well, she was a demonic bitch that would change your life drastically, but you could be simply tired because of two stressful days. Time was passing slowly. Annoyingly, the whole Internet you scrolled was boring. Maybe you had to watch a film.<<nobr>><<if visited("Try not to sleep") gte 2>><br><br>That was strange. You watched 3 films on the "Bug wars" channel and still were sleepy. Usually, the sight of scolopendra was enough to make your heart race, and the fight mantis versus scolopendra was like a spin-off of "Alien vs Predator". But you were yawning so hard that your jaw actually caused a strange clicky sound and ached a little.<</if>><<if visited("Try not to sleep")==3>><br><br>You opened the window. That was a cold April night. A light wind sobered you a little. This night reminded you of the night watches during scouts' camps. The difference was that you really didn't sleep all time. On those camps you kept a guard with ''<<print $they.justinName>>'' or ''<<print $they.oliviaFemaleName>>'' and you were napping in turns. <br><br>Most of the night passed. Your clock beeped at 3.00 AM. Then...<</if>><</nobr>></p><<if visited("Try not to sleep")==3>>[[...your phone buzzed.|Martha's call]]<<else>>[[You tried not to close your eyes!|Temptations]] [[You fell asleep.|Third dream]]<</if>> <<set $resistance = $resistance -1>> <<if $resistance gt 0>><<goto "Try not to sleep">><<else>><<goto "Third dream">><</if>><<nobr>><<set $count = $count+1>><</nobr>><p>You sighed. ''<<print $they.justinName>>''. He would be the only one of your closest friends who forgot you. He never crossed the threshold of ''Rosset high school'', he didn't meet the terror lurking in the shadow of the ''Auntie's'' bust. He knew the other shadows, though. ''<<print $they.oliviaFemaleName>>'' was a partner in discovering the world and accomplice in the wildest ideas. ''<<print $they.dorothyName>>'' was demanding companion and sometimes a rival. But ''<<print $they.justinName>>'' was like a brother. Your father and mother cared about him more than his own parents. You'd never met nicer boy than ''<<print $they.justinName>>''. He had this natural kindness that was impossible to learn. His calm voice, mild eyes, and always serious face always made you feel safe. You'd never heard him complaining. However, you should. ''<<print $they.oliviaFemaleName>>'' once said that ''<<print $they.justinName>>'' had a double citizenship because he raised in Hell. His parents drank. His father was aggressive and beat him and his mother. ''<<print $they.justinName>>'' was always scared and hungry kid. He had no toys. Even when he was a five-year-old kid, he wandered around without a care. He stayed away from kids on the playground. They laughed at his height and his dirty clothes. He played with the kittens from basements. When you finally met you became best friends. Your parents persuaded his mother to let him on the holidays with you. It was a time your mother started to work as a social worker and ''<<print $they.justinName>>'s'' parents wanted to use their son to establish a familiarity with this young, idealistic woman. They counted on the special treatment when they applied for benefits. They underestimated her. You thought about your common history and you felt anger. Some ''<<print $you.femaleName>>'' took your place. When ''<<print $they.justinName>>'' would come on Friday to the city for a concert, it'd be worse than you were dead to him. You'd never exist.</p><<nobr>><<if not visited("Dorothy")>>[[$they.dorothyName|Dorothy]]<br><</if>> <<if visited("Justin") and visited("Dorothy")>>[[You decided to leave the photo on the wall.|Leave it on the wall]]<br> [[You took photo of the wall.|Take it off]]<</if>><</nobr>><<nobr>><<set $count = $count+1>><</nobr>><p>''<<print $they.dorothyName>>'' was your first girlfriend. You didn't talk about her with anyone, however, people were asking you. You were still angry at her. She entered your life later than ''<<print $they.oliviaFemaleName>>'' and ''<<print $they.justinName>>''. You were twelve, she was thirteen. She moved in because her father got the position of the head physician in the local hospital. Her parents bought the apartment in one of the renovated tenement houses. Compared to typical residents in this neighborhood, ''<<print $they.dorothyName>>'s'' family was rich. The owner of the tenement house hired security and receptionists. The estate of renovated buildings was fenced off. It was an isolated island of wealth among poverty. You met her because of your mother. It was her first cadence as a councilor. She commanded you to go to the town hall at the Christmas meeting. You had to be charming for all these old men and women. ''<<print $they.dorothyName>>'s'' father attended this meeting. He brought his daughter to build a positive image. You both were outraged by this hypocrisy. You shared a disgust. You became friends. ''<<print $they.dorothyName>>'' was neglected like ''<<print $they.oliviaFemaleName>>'', her family was wealthier than yours but you both belonged to middle class. The mechanics concentrate on ''Approaches'', ''Stats'' and your choices. Icons such as <<flashy $display>> next to the link mean that by choosing it you'll gain the next level in that ''Approach''. The names of the main cast are ''bold''. These characters also have their own dialogue color. The changes in mechanics (like the changes of ''Stats'' or ''Approaches'') are marked in <span class="displaytext">green color</span>. Whole paragraphs written in //italic// show the hidden content. Have fun!</p>[[Prologue|Sleep]]<<nobr>><<set $count = $count+1>><</nobr>><p>You were in the bathroom in your home. It looked different but familiar. Ceramic tiles were blue, just like they were when you were a child. You look at the bathtub and your heart sank. You recognized the toys you used to play with as a kid. You were a dinosaur freak then. You were proud of your collection of plastic reptiles. Then you saw something you didn't remember. It was a Barbie mermaid. You turned around to confirm. You looked at the dirty clothes in a bowl next to the washing machine. There were a lot of definitely pink, girly tops and skirts. Was it the past? The version of history where you were born and raised as a girl? <span class="maletext">"We will wash our hands, ok, Rita?"</span> You shuddered. It was your father's voice. Rita? But it meant that... The door to the bathroom opened. The woman who went in didn't see you. You weren't surprised. You started to realize that you were just a spectator. But you were touched. Of course, you recognized her. She was aunt Rita, your neighbor's daughter. She had Down Syndrome and died several years ago. She was the most cheerful and warm person you ever met. You missed her. She looked like thirty, so the scene you saw had to take place a year or two before she died. Her hands were smeared with paint. Your father went in and helped him to wash. He looked far worse than now. He was pale and tired, unshaved. Aunt Rita stained his shirt with yellow paint. Oh no. You knew what event ''Auntie'' wanted to show you. You heard the childish giggles before two toddlers ran into the bathroom. They were about eight. A boy wore glasses and too big clothes. His pant legs were rolled up. His fair shag was unruly like always. ''<<print $they.justinName>>''. The resolute girl with pigtails could be only... <span class="maletext">"''<<print $you.femaleName>>''!"</span> your father exclaimed. <span class="maletext">"What did I tell you about running in house? Especially in bathroom!"</span> ''<<print $they.justinName>>'' blushed furiously. Like always, the slightest reprimand hurt him like a blow. But ''<<print $you.femaleName>>'' just smiled. You knew what she would tell. You told that long ago.</p>[["We are running from the vampires, dad!"]]<<nobr>><<set $count = $count+1>><</nobr>><p><span class="yourfemaletext">"We are running from the vampires, dad!"</span> Aunt ''Rita'' bulged her eyes out. Some of them were old, but most of them were fresh. You couldn't understand how this boy could even stand. Your parents exchanged glances. You knew how this situation was handled, so you didn't listen carefully. They decided to call ''Kate'', uncle ''Stan's'' wife, who was a doctor. There was a discussion between the adults about what they should do. They knew the law, they should report it to the police, but your mother as a social worker knew that the government wanted to protect families what meant that there was a little chance that ''<<print $they.justinName>>'' would be taken from his parents. Besides, in the poverty and violence in your district, most children would be in an orphanage if the law was respected strictly. They made the x-ray and it turned out that ''<<print $they.justinName>>'' had no permanent damages, but he should lie down for a week or two. It was impossible to get him a place in the hospital. His return to the flat was a bad idea too, as his unemployed father was there all the time. The solution was strange to you, considering how your mother was strict and lawful. She and ''Kate'' talked with ''<<print $they.justinName>>'s'' mother and warned her that this situation couldn't be repeated or she would lose benefit. It turned out that threat worked, ''<<print $they.justinName>>'s'' father didn't raise his hand on his son until his death 4 years later. ''<<print $they.justinName>>'' remained with your family for two weeks for a total recovery. You remembered that all. You looked at two toddlers who were sitting next to each other and holding hands. You couldn't know that yet, but Bunny Lady was a preview of many of your academic teachers. She was lazy and she didn't care if she taught you anything. She assumed that if she was understanding to students they wouldn't report her as a horrible teacher. Well, it worked. Even people who wanted to write an exam in Social Studies didn't complain. Students in ''Rosset High School'' needed such a place like Warren, the safe heaven in stressful school life. ''Popularity:'' this stat represents how ''<<print $you.maleName>>'' is seen in the eyes of people around him. ''Grades:'' this stat represents how ''<<print $you.maleName>>'' handles his school duties. ''Privacy:'' this stat represents if ''<<print $you.maleName>>'' can keep his thoughts and actions secret. There was a buffet where you could buy toasts or casseroles, but you couldn't really name it lunch. A school had liberal rules, so adult (or almost adult) students were allowed to go out for lunch or order it to the school building. It was common that during the long break students sat on the benches at the schoolyard and ate pizza or Chinese food. There were plenty of restaurants and pubs nearby. ''Rosset High School'' was next to the main street of the district. When four years ago your mother said about the plans that this street could be closed at weekends to make the promenade you and your father laughed at this idea as surrealist. Most of the tenement houses were devastated and dirty, restaurants were cheap places for local drinkers. When the subway station was opened here, there were alarming articles in the press that local criminals would use the subway to expand the area for their actions. Nothing like that happened. The lower prices caused that students started to rent flats here. The young people needed a place to eat and drink. Thank to the subway people could go to the city center in 10 minutes. Many offices moved here, encouraged by the accounts and friendly politics of the district's authorities. It was a slow process, but now the main street was a mix of old poverty and new vintage and hipster places. In the middle of your transformation, you felt unsure if you should stay or go. For school students, you were some sensation, for people in the street you were just ordinary schoolgirl. But you didn't get used to your new voice and appearance. Like most of the buildings in the neighborhood, it was built in the nineteenth century. It was closed in the early 1990s and abandoned to deteriorate for 20 years. Now, renovated, it was a space for lofts and offices. The restaurant looked fancy. The theme was pandas. If Bunny Lady reorganized the Warren as a restaurant, it would look like a tasteless version of this place. There were photos and frescos. Stuffed pandas sat on the reserved seats. You were shocked. Was she making you a kid again? But the changes only slower, but didn't end. Your face tingled again. Your nose looked smaller, the chin bones were a little higher. Your lips darkened a little. Your eyebrows looked less prominent, your jaw rounded. There were subtle changes, but when they occurred you looked like a twelve-year-old girl. Then your face shifted. Your eyes seemed to be smaller, your eyelashes thicked and grew. Your skin was soft and flexible, however, you saw some reddish spots on them. It had to be your allergy to lactose. Of course, the politicians had to do it with a huge bureaucracy - the employer had to pay all dues and the employee later had to apply for money in the local tax office. And tax offices... well... didn't work too fast. Helping in this bookshop was your first real job. Earlier you did some season jobs, like snow removal or walking the dogs, but it was pointless work for pointless pay your parents were finding you to create the illusion that they were teaching you the responsibility. The evening was warm and pleasant. You took the headphones into your ears and launched Spotify. The park seemed to crowdy for you, so you decided to go to the river. Riverbank on this side was still wild and neglected. There was a path for cyclists and walkers and several beaches where people set campfires, but most of the area was covered by high grass, bushes, and trees. Some people jogged here or even were fishing, but it was calm and quiet. You needed such relaxation. As your city was surrounded by woods, the boars were a solid problem for evening walkers. You didn't meet them, but you heard them, so you decided to climb on the embankment. You had a great view of the center's panorama with its skyscrapers and lights. On the other side, you saw the chimneys of mostly closed factories. And in the middle of those sights of the modern city, you were in the wilderness only with boars and birds. The contrasts in your city never stopped to surprise you. But then, when you followed the path through the embankment you realized it was a good allegory of your own life. Was there any barrier that could stop ''Auntie''? The flashy of the center was certainly across the river of your doubts and fears. And you were terribly alone there. You sighed. Your loneliness was complete. You turned around, but you only heard the noises of cars crossing the bridge. You knew this area, you were here quite often. It was the first time since your transformation you could mingle with the crowd. Finally, you got some privacy. Of course, as a young woman, you weren't as invisible as you were before, but you were still more comfortable than you were at school. Some people stared at you because they saw a cute girl, not that you were transformed into one. It was odd just to walk into the mall without a purpose. As always, you were surprised about the amount of discounted books. You sometimes bought one of them, however, they were often a total crap. As your father was a graphic, you could recognize the stock pictures used on the covers. They barely fit the content of the books. Most of the books were translations of American authors. The horror writers in your country had a little chance to be published in the bigger publishing houses. But there was an exception. You saw a book titled "The recognition of spirits". The stock blond and busty teenage girl was shouting on the cover. But there was a subheading that you found interesting. "Is your high school cursed too"? You took the book. The author was from your city and it was his debut as a fiction writer but he published already some articles about occultism. It turned out that the plot of his book was about the cursed school where some kind of evil spirits persuaded students to commit suicide. Well, it was interesting. The occult writers usually wrote terribly. You tried to read some classics of the matter, but you didn't learn much. And as the book cost $2.50, you didn't hesitate long.
